Avian influenza H5N1 HA binds alpha-2,3-sialic acid poorly binds alpha-2,6-sialic acid (human upper respiratory tract). Innate immune evasion: The virus must counteract human interferon responses. Species-specific restriction factors (TRIM5alpha, tetherin/BST-2, APOBEC3G, MxA) may block replication of animal viruses in human cells. (3) Adaptation barrier: Polymerase adaptation: Avian influenza PB2 has E627 which functions well at avian body temperature (40-41C) but poorly at human upper airway temperature (33C). The E627K mutation adapts the polymerase to mammalian temperature. Codon usage optimization improves translation efficiency. (4) Transmission barrier: Most critical and least frequently crossed. The virus must replicate to high titers, be present in transmissible body fluids/aerosols, survive in the environment, and infect new hosts before the current host dies. The R0 must exceed 1 for sustained transmission. (5) Examples: SARS-CoV-2 had high ACE2 binding affinity and a furin cleavage site enabling pandemic spread. HIV-1 had multiple cross-species transmissions from chimpanzees but only Group M achieved pandemic spread. Ebola repeatedly spills over from bats but has limited human-to-human transmission (R0 = 1.5-2.5, requires direct contact with body fluids).

questions.question: A researcher wants to create a recombinant viral vaccine vector that expresses a foreign antigen but cannot revert to a virulent form. Which approach would provide the safest replication-incompetent viral vector while maintaining immunogenicity?
options: Simply attenuate the virus through serial passage in cell culture until it loses virulence
Use UV irradiation to inactivate the virus while preserving surface antigen structure
Insert the foreign antigen gene without modifying any viral genes to maintain full replication capacity

Delete one or more essential viral genes from the viral genome and supply these genes in trans from a complementing cell line; the recombinant virus can replicate in the complementing cell line for production but undergoes only a single round of infection in normal cells, expressing the foreign antigen and stimulating immune responses without producing infectious progeny
questions.explanation: Replication-incompetent viral vectors: (1) Design principle: Essential viral genes are deleted from the viral genome. The foreign antigen gene is inserted in place of or alongside remaining viral genes. A complementing cell line stably expresses the deleted essential gene(s). In complementing cells: vector genome is replicated, viral proteins including the complemented essential protein are expressed, and infectious vector particles are assembled. In normal cells: the vector can infect and express the foreign antigen but CANNOT produce infectious progeny because the essential gene product is absent. (2) Examples: Adenovirus vectors (Ad5, Ad26, ChAdOx1): E1 gene region deleted. Produced in HEK293 cells expressing Ad5 E1. Used in COVID-19 vaccines (J&J Ad26.COV2.S, AstraZeneca ChAdOx1-S). Modified Vaccinia Ankara (MVA): Lost ~30 kb of genome through >570 passages. Can infect mammalian cells but cannot complete replication cycle. Lentiviral vectors (from HIV-1): Third-generation vectors split essential genes across 4 plasmids. Self-inactivating design with deleted U3 promoter. (3) Safety advantages: No risk of reversion to virulence (unlike live attenuated vaccines in option B). Safe for immunocompromised individuals. Better immunogenicity than inactivated vaccines (option D) because intracellular antigen production stimulates both MHC-I and MHC-II pathways. (4) Limitations: Lower immunogenicity per dose compared to replication-competent vectors. Requires specialized complementing cell lines. Pre-existing immunity to vector can reduce effectiveness.

questions.question: Abortive infection systems (Abi) represent a bacterial population-level defense against bacteriophages. How do Abi systems protect bacterial populations despite killing the infected cell?
options: Abi systems repair phage-damaged DNA and restore the cell to normal function
Abi systems transfer phage resistance genes to neighboring cells via conjugation
Abi systems simply slow down phage replication without killing the host cell

Abi systems are altruistic suicide mechanisms: when triggered by phage infection, they kill the infected cell before phage replication is complete, preventing release of progeny phages that would infect neighboring cells; examples include the Rex system of lambda (which collapses membrane potential), toxin-antitoxin systems activated by phage interference with host gene expression, and retron-based defense systems that detect phage proteins and trigger cell death
questions.explanation: Abortive infection systems: (1) Concept: Abi systems sacrifice the infected cell to protect the bacterial population. This is programmed cell death analogous to apoptosis in multicellular organisms. (2) The Rex system (lambda prophage-encoded): RexA is activated by phage DNA-protein complexes. RexA activates RexB, an inner membrane ion channel. RexB collapses the membrane potential causing ATP depletion, cessation of macromolecular synthesis, and cell death before the phage completes its replication cycle. (3) Toxin-antitoxin (TA) systems: Normal state: labile antitoxin neutralizes the toxin. During phage infection: if the phage disrupts host gene expression, the labile antitoxin is degraded faster than replenished. Free toxin kills the cell. Examples: MazE/MazF (mRNA interferase), ToxI/ToxN (endoribonuclease). Phages counter TA systems by encoding antitoxin mimics (T4 Dmd protein). (4) Retron-based defense: Retrons produce multicopy single-stranded DNA via reverse transcriptase. The retron functions as a sensor — phage-encoded anti-defense proteins inadvertently trigger the retron sensor, activating an effector toxin that kills the cell. (5) CBASS system: Phage infection activates a cGAS/DncV-like nucleotidyltransferase producing cyclic oligonucleotides that activate effector proteins (phospholipases, endonucleases, pore-forming proteins) killing the cell. Analogous to the mammalian cGAS-STING pathway. (6) Kin selection: Abi is maintained because the cost to the individual is outweighed by the benefit to clonal relatives, especially when phage burst size is large.

questions.question: A phylogenetic analysis of influenza A virus hemagglutinin sequences reveals that the rate of synonymous substitutions (dS) is approximately 5 x 10^-3 substitutions/site/year, while the rate of nonsynonymous substitutions (dN) at antigenic sites is approximately 8 x 10^-3 substitutions/site/year (dN/dS = 1.6). What evolutionary process does this dN/dS ratio indicate?
options: A dN/dS ratio of 1.6 indicates neutral evolution with no selective pressure

A dN/dS ratio greater than 1 indicates positive (diversifying) selection at these antigenic sites, meaning amino acid changes are being selectively favored because they help the virus escape pre-existing antibody immunity in the host population; this contrasts with the genome-wide dN/dS of ~0.1-0.3, which indicates purifying selection maintaining protein function at most sites
This ratio indicates purifying selection removing harmful mutations from the viral population
The dN/dS ratio indicates the virus is evolving more slowly than expected under neutral drift
questions.explanation: dN/dS analysis and influenza evolution: (1) Understanding dN/dS: dS is the rate of synonymous (silent) mutations serving as the neutral baseline. dN is the rate of nonsynonymous (amino acid-changing) mutations subject to selection. (2) Interpretation: dN/dS < 1: Purifying selection (amino acid changes removed as deleterious). dN/dS = 1: Neutral evolution. dN/dS > 1: Positive selection (amino acid changes favored). (3) Influenza HA antigenic sites: dN/dS = 1.6 means amino acid substitutions are occurring 60% faster than neutral expectation. This is strong evidence for immune-driven positive selection (antigenic drift). Viruses with altered antigenic sites escape pre-existing antibodies, gaining reproductive advantage. (4) Contrast with other regions: Receptor binding residues show dN/dS << 1 (must maintain function). HA2 fusion domain shows dN/dS < 0.3 (structural conservation). Only exposed antigenic epitopes show dN/dS > 1. (5) Methods: Site-specific analysis (PAML, HyPhy) identifies individual codons under selection. dN/dS > 1 is also found in HIV envelope, HCV hypervariable region, and coronavirus spike RBD.
questions.topic: dN/dS ratio and positive selection in influenza

questions.question: Programmed ribosomal frameshifting is used by many viruses to regulate the ratio of different protein products. How does the -1 ribosomal frameshift mechanism work in HIV-1 to produce the Gag-Pol polyprotein?
options: An internal ribosome entry site between gag and pol initiates independent translation of Pol
HIV-1 produces Gag and Pol from two separate mRNAs generated by alternative splicing
Gag and Pol are produced from the same reading frame with no frameshift required

A slippery sequence (UUUUUUA) causes the ribosome to shift one nucleotide in the 5' direction at ~5-10% frequency, allowing read-through of the gag stop codon into the pol reading frame; efficiency is enhanced by a downstream RNA secondary structure that pauses the ribosome at the slippery site, and this ratio ensures Gag is produced in ~20-fold excess over Gag-Pol, maintaining correct stoichiometry for virion assembly
questions.explanation: Programmed -1 ribosomal frameshifting in HIV-1: (1) Context: gag and pol are in overlapping reading frames, with pol in the -1 frame relative to gag. A stop codon at the end of gag normally terminates translation. (2) The slippery sequence: U UUU UUA allows simultaneous tRNA slippage at the A and P sites. After slipping one nucleotide 5'-ward, tRNAs can re-pair in the -1 frame due to the repetitive sequence. Translation continues through pol. (3) Stimulatory RNA structure: A stem-loop downstream causes ribosome pausing, increasing frameshifting probability. (4) Stoichiometry: ~5-10% frameshifting produces ~10-20:1 Gag:Gag-Pol ratio. This is critical: too much Gag-Pol causes premature protease activation and defective assembly; too little means insufficient RT and IN. Even 2-fold changes in frameshifting are lethal. (5) Processing: Gag-Pol is incorporated into virions alongside Gag. The protease domain self-activates as a homodimer and cleaves both polyproteins into MA, CA, NC, p6, PR, RT, and IN. Protease inhibitors target this step. (6) Other viruses using -1 frameshifting: Coronaviruses (ORF1a/1b junction, ~25-30% efficiency using a pseudoknot), HTLV-1, astroviruses, and many plant viruses. Frameshifting itself is a potential antiviral drug target.

questions.question: How does the self-assembly of TMV (helical) differ mechanistically from the assembly of icosahedral viruses like poliovirus?
options: TMV assembles via nucleation-elongation: a 20S protein disk binds a specific origin-of-assembly sequence on the RNA, then additional subunits add as RNA threads through the growing helix; poliovirus follows hierarchical assembly where 5S protomers form 14S pentamers, twelve pentamers assemble into an empty 75S procapsid, then genomic RNA is inserted, and VP0 is autocatalytically cleaved to VP4+VP2 to yield the mature 160S virion
TMV assembles inside the nucleus while poliovirus assembles in the cytoplasm
Both viruses require the host endoplasmic reticulum for assembly
Both TMV and poliovirus assemble by simultaneous condensation of protein around pre-formed RNA
questions.explanation: Viral assembly pathways: (1) TMV helical assembly (elucidated by Aaron Klug, Nobel 1982): Coat protein forms 20S disk aggregates (two-layered ring of 34 subunits). Nucleation: 20S disk binds to the origin-of-assembly sequence ~900 nt from the 3' end. Upon RNA binding, the disk transitions from flat ring to helical lock-washer conformation. Elongation: Additional disks add, RNA threads through central channel. Proceeds bidirectionally but faster toward 5' end. Each subunit binds 3 nucleotides. Final: ~300 nm rod, 2130 CP subunits, 16.33 subunits per turn. Key: RNA is essential for nucleation; no empty capsid forms. (2) Poliovirus icosahedral assembly: P1 precursor is cleaved by 3CDpro into VP0, VP3, VP1. 5S protomer: VP0+VP3+VP1. 14S pentamer: five protomers. 75S empty capsid: twelve pentamers assemble without RNA. RNA packaging: (+) ssRNA is inserted into procapsid. Maturation: VP0 autocatalytically cleaved to VP4+VP2 (catalyzed by conserved His and RNA backbone). This stabilizes the capsid enormously. Key: Empty capsid forms first; RNA packaging is separate. (3) Distinction: TMV couples assembly and RNA packaging; poliovirus separates them. This matters for VLP vaccines — poliovirus-like assembly allows icosahedral VLPs without nucleic acid (HPV Gardasil, HBV vaccine).

questions.question: Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) establishes lifelong latency in sensory neurons. What molecular mechanisms maintain latency and trigger reactivation?
options: The viral genome integrates into neuronal chromosomes during latency like a retrovirus

During latency, the HSV-1 genome exists as a circular episome in neuronal nuclei with lytic genes silenced by heterochromatin marks (H3K9me3, H3K27me3); the only abundant transcript is the latency-associated transcript (LAT), a non-coding RNA that inhibits apoptosis and promotes heterochromatin on lytic promoters; reactivation is triggered by stress signals activating JNK kinase, leading to histone demethylation and derepression of immediate-early genes, especially ICP0 which is a ubiquitin ligase that degrades host repressors like PML bodies
HSV-1 latency is maintained by continuous low-level replication suppressed by T-cell surveillance
Latency is maintained by viral DNA methylation that permanently silences the genome
questions.explanation: HSV-1 latency and reactivation: (1) Establishment: After primary mucosal infection, HSV-1 enters sensory nerve terminals and is transported retrograde to ganglia. In neuronal nuclei, linear viral DNA (152 kb) circularizes. Lytic gene expression is silenced. (2) Chromatin silencing: Viral DNA acquires repressive histone marks: H3K9me3 (deposited by SUV39H1/2, recognized by HP1) and H3K27me3 (deposited by PRC2/EZH2). These create heterochromatin on lytic gene promoters. (3) LAT: The only abundant latency transcript. A long non-coding RNA producing a stable 2 kb intron. Functions: anti-apoptotic (inhibits caspases 8 and 9, critical for neuronal survival), encodes viral miRNAs (miR-H2, miR-H6) that target ICP0 and ICP4 mRNAs, and promotes H3K27me3 deposition on lytic genes (analogous to XIST). (4) Reactivation triggers: UV, fever, emotional stress, immunosuppression, nerve injury. These activate JNK/p38 MAPK which activate histone demethylases (JMJD3 for H3K27me3, KDM4 for H3K9me3). Phase I transcription occurs genome-wide at low levels. If sufficient IE expression occurs, ICP0 (RING finger E3 ubiquitin ligase) degrades PML nuclear bodies, IFI16, and disperses repressive chromatin. This triggers the full lytic cascade leading to reactivation. (5) Immune surveillance: CD8+ T cells in ganglia suppress reactivation via granzyme B (cleaves ICP4) and IFN-gamma, creating dynamic equilibrium with occasional breakthrough.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about viral evolution and emergence:

S1: RNA viruses generally evolve faster than DNA viruses because RNA-dependent RNA polymerases lack proofreading activity, leading to mutation rates approximately 10,000-fold higher than DNA viruses.

S2: Reassortment is the exchange of entire genome segments between two related viruses co-infecting the same cell, responsible for pandemic influenza strains through antigenic shift.

S3: Recombination in RNA viruses occurs through a template-switching copy-choice mechanism where the RdRp jumps from one RNA template to another during replication.

S4: All RNA viruses have higher mutation rates than all DNA viruses, with no exceptions or overlap between the two groups.
options: T, T, T, F
T, T, T, T
T, T, F, F
F, T, T, F
questions.explanation: Analyzing viral evolution statements: S1 TRUE: RdRps lack 3'-to-5' exonuclease proofreading (except coronavirus nsp14 ExoN). RNA virus mutation rates are ~10^-3 to 10^-5 per nucleotide per replication, compared to ~10^-7 to 10^-9 for DNA viruses. This drives rapid adaptation but limits genome size. S2 TRUE: Reassortment occurs in segmented genome viruses (influenza, rotavirus, bunyaviruses). When two viruses co-infect, genome segments can be randomly assorted into progeny. Historic events: 1957 H2N2, 1968 H3N2, 2009 H1N1 all involved reassortment producing major antigenic shifts. S3 TRUE: RNA recombination occurs through copy-choice template switching — RdRp pauses on one template, transfers to another with the nascent strand still attached, and continues synthesis. Frequent in coronaviruses, picornaviruses, and retroviruses (2-3 crossovers per HIV genome per cycle). HIV circulating recombinant forms represent ~20% of global infections. S4 FALSE: While broadly true, there is overlap. Small ssDNA viruses (parvoviruses, geminiviruses) have mutation rates approaching RNA viruses (~10^-4 to 10^-5) because ssDNA is susceptible to oxidative damage. Conversely, coronaviruses with ExoN proofreading have rates (~10^-6 to 10^-7) overlapping with some DNA viruses.
questions.topic: Viral evolution mechanisms and mutation rates

questions.question: The type I interferon response is the primary innate immune defense against viral infection in vertebrates. How do cells detect viral infection and initiate interferon production?
options: Viruses are detected exclusively by antibodies that trigger interferon from B cells

Cells detect viral infection through pattern recognition receptors that recognize viral PAMPs: cytoplasmic RIG-I detects 5'-triphosphate short dsRNA, MDA5 detects long dsRNA, cGAS detects cytoplasmic DNA, and endosomal TLR3/7/8/9 detect dsRNA, ssRNA, and CpG DNA; these sensors converge on IRF3/IRF7 and NF-kappaB transcription factors that induce type I interferon expression, which signals through IFNAR via JAK-STAT to induce hundreds of interferon-stimulated genes creating an antiviral state
Only specialized immune cells can detect viral infection; non-immune cells have no antiviral sensing
Interferon is constitutively expressed and does not require viral infection for production
questions.explanation: Innate antiviral interferon response: (1) Viral PAMPs: dsRNA (replication intermediates), 5'-triphosphate RNA (viral polymerase products lacking caps), cytoplasmic DNA (DNA viruses, retroviruses), CpG-rich DNA. (2) Cytoplasmic RNA sensors: RIG-I detects short dsRNA with 5'ppp (influenza, Sendai, Ebola, HCV). MDA5 detects long dsRNA (picornaviruses, coronaviruses). Both signal through mitochondrial adaptor MAVS. (3) DNA sensor: cGAS detects cytoplasmic dsDNA, synthesizes 2'3'-cGAMP which activates STING on ER, recruiting TBK1 to phosphorylate IRF3. Key for herpesviruses, adenoviruses, retroviruses. (4) Endosomal TLRs: TLR3 (dsRNA via TRIF), TLR7/8 (ssRNA via MyD88), TLR9 (CpG DNA via MyD88). (5) Signaling convergence: All sensors activate IRF3/IRF7 + NF-kappaB which form an enhanceosome on the IFN-beta promoter. (6) IFN signaling: Secreted IFN-alpha/beta binds IFNAR, activates JAK1/TYK2, phosphorylates STAT1/STAT2 which form ISGF3 with IRF9, inducing ISGs. (7) Key ISGs: MxA (blocks nucleocapsid transport), OAS/RNase L (degrades RNA), PKR (phosphorylates eIF2alpha shutting down translation), IFITM (blocks viral fusion), tetherin (blocks enveloped virus release), APOBEC3G (deaminates retroviral cDNA).

questions.question: Negative-stain electron microscopy reveals a virus with a bullet-shaped morphology approximately 180 nm long and 75 nm wide, with a helical nucleocapsid inside an envelope. To which viral family does this virus most likely belong?
options: Filoviridae, whose members form long filamentous particles

Rhabdoviridae, as the distinctive bullet shape with a helical nucleocapsid wrapped inside a lipid envelope studded with glycoprotein G trimeric spikes is pathognomonic for this family, which includes rabies virus and vesicular stomatitis virus
Paramyxoviridae, whose members form pleomorphic spherical particles
Orthomyxoviridae, whose members are spherical with a segmented genome
questions.explanation: Viral morphology and classification: (1) Rhabdoviridae: Unique bullet shape (flat base, rounded tip) among animal viruses. ~100-430 nm x 45-100 nm. Internal: (-) ssRNA (~12 kb) encapsidated by N protein in helical RNP. M protein creates the bullet shape by bridging RNP and envelope. ~400 trimeric G protein spikes. Key members: rabies virus, VSV. (2) Filoviridae (option B): Filamentous/threadlike, up to 14,000 nm long, uniform ~80 nm diameter. Ebola and Marburg. (3) Paramyxoviridae (option C): Spherical to pleomorphic, 150-350 nm. Measles, mumps, RSV, Nipah. NOT bullet-shaped. (4) Orthomyxoviridae (option D): Spherical ~100 nm to filamentous. HA and NA spikes. Segmented genome. NOT bullet-shaped. Morphology remains valuable for rapid virus identification even with modern molecular methods.
questions.topic: Viral morphology identification by electron microscopy

questions.question: Bacteriophage Mu uses transposition as its primary DNA replication mechanism. How does Mu replicative transposition differ from conservative transposition, and why is this an effective replication strategy?
options: Mu replicative transposition cuts Mu DNA out of the donor and pastes it at a new location

In Mu replicative transposition, MuA transposase nicks each end of Mu DNA and makes staggered cuts at the target site, then joins Mu 3'-OH ends to target 5'-phosphates WITHOUT excising Mu from the donor; the resulting Shapiro intermediate is resolved by host replication machinery copying the Mu DNA, doubling copy number with each event and amplifying from 1 to ~100 copies during the lytic cycle
Mu transposes via an RNA intermediate like retrotransposons
Mu uses a standard bidirectional replication fork from a viral origin
questions.explanation: Phage Mu replicative transposition: (1) Overview: Mu (Mutator phage, ~37 kb) uses transposition rather than conventional replication. Named because Mu insertion causes mutations at high frequency. (2) Lysogenic integration: initial conservative transposition into host chromosome. (3) Lytic replicative transposition: MuA nicks Mu ends (exposing 3'-OH) but does NOT cleave the 5' ends (Mu stays connected to donor). Target capture: MuB delivers target DNA, staggered 5 bp cuts in target. Strand transfer: Mu 3'-OH joined to target 5'-P. Shapiro intermediate: branched DNA connecting donor and target. Host replication forks assemble at each junction, replicate through Mu DNA, doubling copy number. (4) Amplification: 1 → 2 → 4 → ... → ~100 copies in 40-60 min. This IS the replication mechanism. (5) Comparison with conservative transposition (Tn5, Tn10): conservative cuts both strands at both ends, excises the element, and inserts at new site — copy number stays constant. Replicative cuts only one strand at each end, doesn't excise, and replication doubles copy number. (6) Packaging: ~39 kb headful includes ~50-150 bp flanking host DNA at each end (variable end sequences).

questions.question: Enveloped viruses acquire their lipid bilayer during egress. What are the different budding strategies employed by enveloped viruses?
options: All enveloped viruses bud exclusively from the plasma membrane through the same mechanism

Different viruses bud from different cellular membranes: influenza and HIV bud from the plasma membrane (HIV uses ESCRT machinery via Gag p6 L-domain motifs PTAP and LYPXnL recruiting Tsg101 and ALIX); coronaviruses bud into the ERGIC compartment; herpesviruses undergo primary envelopment at the inner nuclear membrane, de-envelopment at the outer nuclear membrane, and re-envelopment at trans-Golgi membranes
Enveloped viruses acquire their membranes during entry rather than egress
Viral envelopes are synthesized de novo by viral enzymes rather than derived from cellular membranes
questions.explanation: Enveloped virus budding strategies: (1) Plasma membrane budding — Influenza: HA and NA are transported to apical plasma membrane. M1 bridges RNPs to cytoplasmic tails of glycoproteins. M2 ion channel also incorporated. Budding likely driven by M1 oligomerization curving the membrane. NA cleaves sialic acid to prevent self-aggregation. HIV-1: Gag is myristoylated, targets PI(4,5)P2-rich membrane domains. Gag oligomerizes forming immature particle. ESCRT recruitment via p6 L-domains: PTAP recruits Tsg101 (ESCRT-I), LYPXnL recruits ALIX. ESCRT-III spirals drive membrane scission. Without ESCRT, buds remain tethered. (2) Intracellular budding — Coronaviruses: S, M, E proteins inserted in ER. M protein defines budding at ERGIC. N-M interaction drives nucleocapsid packaging. Released via exocytosis. Bunyaviruses: Gn/Gc localize to Golgi, RNPs bud into Golgi lumen. (3) Herpesvirus triple envelopment: Primary envelopment at inner nuclear membrane (capsid too large for nuclear pores). UL31-UL34 NEC mediates INM budding. De-envelopment: primary envelope fuses with outer nuclear membrane, releasing naked capsid. Re-envelopment: tegumented capsid buds into TGN/endosomal membranes bearing viral glycoproteins. Released by exocytosis. This three-step process is unique to herpesviruses.

questions.question: NGS sequencing of SARS-CoV-2 isolates from 20 patients in a hospital cluster shows all share a D614G spike mutation plus 3 unique SNPs absent from community isolates. The phylogenetic tree shows all 20 forming a monophyletic clade with <2 SNP differences between any pair. What can be concluded?
options: The patients were all independently infected from community sources sharing the same mutations
Sequencing cannot distinguish hospital-acquired from community-acquired infections

The data strongly support a single-source nosocomial outbreak: the monophyletic clustering with minimal genetic diversity indicates all infections descended from a recent common ancestor; the 3 unique shared SNPs serve as a genomic signature distinguishing this from community transmission, and short branch lengths indicate rapid person-to-person spread within the hospital
The D614G mutation alone proves hospital transmission
questions.explanation: Genomic epidemiology: (1) SARS-CoV-2 evolves at ~2 substitutions/genome/month. Sequences from the same transmission chain sampled within days-weeks should differ by 0-3 SNPs. The <2 SNP differences indicate a very recent common ancestor. (2) Monophyletic clustering means all 20 share a more recent common ancestor with each other than with community isolates. Independent community acquisitions would be polyphyletic (scattered throughout the tree). (3) The 3 unique shared SNPs are genomic markers for this cluster. Probability of the same 3 SNPs arising independently in 20 people is essentially zero across a ~30 kb genome. (4) D614G is globally dominant (not cluster-specific). The distinguishing features are the 3 additional SNPs. (5) Actions: identify the index case, enhanced infection control, contact tracing, environmental sampling, ventilation assessment. Genomic data combined with epidemiological metadata (dates, wards, shared HCWs) reconstructs the transmission network.

questions.question: Poxviruses replicate entirely in the cytoplasm despite being large dsDNA viruses. How do they accomplish DNA replication and mRNA transcription without access to nuclear enzymes?
options: Poxviruses temporarily transport their DNA into the nucleus for replication then return it to the cytoplasm
Poxviruses use reverse transcriptase to replicate their DNA genome
Poxviruses hijack mitochondrial RNA polymerase for their transcription

Poxviruses encode their own complete transcription and replication machinery, including a multi-subunit DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, capping enzyme, poly-A polymerase, and a DNA polymerase with associated processivity factors, all packaged within the virion core; upon entry, early genes are transcribed within the core particle by pre-packaged enzymes before the core fully uncoats
questions.explanation: Poxvirus cytoplasmic replication: (1) Poxviruses (e.g., vaccinia, variola/smallpox) have large dsDNA genomes (~190 kb for vaccinia) encoding ~200 proteins. They are unique among DNA viruses in replicating entirely in the cytoplasm. (2) Virion-packaged enzymes: The poxvirus core contains a complete transcription system. Early gene transcription begins inside the intact core particle within minutes of cell entry, before full uncoating. Packaged enzymes include: multi-subunit RNA polymerase (viral, not host), mRNA capping enzyme (D1/D12), poly-A polymerase, early transcription factor VETF, and topoisomerase. (3) DNA replication: Viral DNA polymerase (E9) with associated processivity factor A20-D4, uracil DNA glycosylase, and a single-stranded DNA binding protein. Replication occurs in cytoplasmic viral factories (virosomes) that are visible as dense inclusions. (4) Genome structure: Linear dsDNA with covalently closed (hairpin) telomeres. Contains inverted terminal repeats (ITRs). Replication initiates near the telomeres and proceeds via concatemer formation, resolved by a viral telomere resolvase. (5) Gene expression cascade: Early genes (transcribed by virion-packaged enzymes) encode intermediate transcription factors, DNA replication machinery, and immune evasion proteins. Intermediate genes (transcribed after DNA replication) encode late transcription factors. Late genes encode structural proteins and enzymes for early transcription. (6) Significance: Poxvirus self-sufficiency for cytoplasmic replication means they can infect enucleated cells (unlike other DNA viruses).

questions.question: Rotaviruses have segmented dsRNA genomes and replicate within cytoplasmic viroplasms. Why must dsRNA viruses keep their genomic RNA inside the viral core during replication?
options: dsRNA is a potent activator of innate immune sensors (RIG-I, MDA5, PKR, OAS) in the cytoplasm; by retaining dsRNA within the core particle during transcription and extruding only (+) mRNAs through channels in the capsid shell, rotaviruses avoid triggering the interferon response, PKR-mediated translational shutoff, and OAS/RNase L-mediated RNA degradation
dsRNA viruses expose their genomes to the cytoplasm just like ssRNA viruses
dsRNA must remain in the core because host ribosomes can only translate dsRNA, not ssRNA
The core particle converts dsRNA to DNA before it can be used as a template
questions.explanation: dsRNA virus immune evasion strategy: (1) dsRNA as a PAMP: Eukaryotic cells do not normally produce long dsRNA. Cytoplasmic dsRNA is recognized as a danger signal by multiple innate immune sensors: RIG-I and MDA5 (signal through MAVS to induce interferons), PKR (phosphorylates eIF2alpha shutting down all translation), OAS/RNase L (2-5A pathway degrades all cellular and viral RNA). Activation of these pathways would be lethal to the virus. (2) Conservative transcription: Rotavirus VP1 (RdRp) and VP3 (capping enzyme) are located inside the double-layered core particle. VP1 transcribes the (-) strand of each dsRNA segment, producing (+) mRNAs. The (+) mRNAs are extruded through channels at the 5-fold vertices of the VP2 inner capsid layer. VP3 caps the 5' end of each mRNA as it exits. The dsRNA genome NEVER leaves the core. This is called conservative transcription. (3) Replication: (+) mRNAs serve dual functions: translated by host ribosomes and serve as templates for (-) strand synthesis. New (-) strands are synthesized inside assembling core particles from the (+) template, generating new dsRNA segments. This occurs within viroplasms — cytoplasmic inclusions that concentrate viral components and exclude innate immune sensors. (4) All dsRNA virus families use this strategy: Reoviridae (rotavirus, reovirus, orbivirus), Birnaviridae, Picobirnaviridae, Totiviridae (fungi). This explains why dsRNA virus particles always contain the RdRp — they MUST transcribe within the particle. (5) Pharmacological relevance: This sequestration is why dsRNA viruses are relatively resistant to ribavirin (which must access the template during replication) and why targeting the transcription channels is a potential antiviral strategy.

questions.question: A viral evolution experiment tracks the fitness of a clonal RNA virus population over serial passage. Initially, fitness increases rapidly for 50 passages, then plateaus. When a high-fitness clone is isolated and passaged again, fitness increases again before reaching a new plateau. This pattern repeats with diminishing gains. What does this trajectory represent?
options: This represents adaptive evolution on a rugged fitness landscape: the initial rapid increase reflects accumulation of beneficial mutations of large effect; the plateau indicates the population has reached a local fitness peak where all single-step mutations are neutral or deleterious; the renewed increase after clonal isolation reflects escape from clonal interference, allowing the population to explore new mutational pathways to higher fitness peaks
Each plateau represents the virus acquiring antibiotic resistance
The pattern represents random genetic drift with no selective component
The plateaus indicate the virus has reached maximum possible fitness and cannot evolve further
questions.explanation: Experimental viral evolution dynamics: (1) Initial rapid adaptation: When a virus is introduced to a new environment (new host cell type, different temperature, presence of a drug), many mutations offer substantial fitness improvements. Beneficial mutations of large effect are quickly selected. This phase follows diminishing returns epistasis — early beneficial mutations have large effects, later ones have progressively smaller effects. (2) Fitness plateau at local peaks: As the most beneficial mutations are fixed, the population approaches a local fitness peak. All or most single-step mutations from this peak are neutral or deleterious. The mutation supply rate (population size x mutation rate) determines how quickly the population can explore multi-step mutational pathways to escape. In large RNA virus populations, multiple beneficial mutations arise simultaneously and compete (clonal interference), slowing adaptation. (3) Clonal isolation effect: Isolating a single high-fitness clone removes the genetic diversity (and clonal interference). From this new starting point, the clone may access different mutational pathways than the diverse population could. This can allow exploration of novel regions of sequence space and escape from the local peak. (4) Diminishing returns: Each successive plateau is harder to surpass because: the remaining beneficial mutations have smaller fitness effects, the population is closer to the global fitness optimum, and compensatory/epistatic constraints increase. (5) Fisher's geometric model: Mutations of large effect are beneficial when far from the optimum but deleterious when close. As fitness increases, the probability that a random mutation is beneficial decreases. (6) Practical implications: This understanding informs vaccine development — live attenuated vaccines can potentially evolve toward higher fitness (reversion to virulence) during passages in the host. Drug resistance evolution follows similar dynamics.

questions.question: Neuraminidase (NA) inhibitors like oseltamivir (Tamiflu) target a specific step in the influenza virus life cycle. What is the precise mechanism of NA inhibitors?
options: NA inhibitors are transition-state analogs that bind the NA active site, blocking its sialidase activity; this prevents the cleavage of sialic acid residues on the host cell surface and newly assembled virions, causing progeny virions to remain tethered to the cell surface and to aggregate with each other through HA-sialic acid interactions, thereby blocking viral spread to new cells while not preventing initial infection or intracellular replication
NA inhibitors directly inhibit the viral RNA polymerase complex
NA inhibitors prevent viral uncoating by blocking M2 ion channel activity
NA inhibitors block viral entry by preventing HA-sialic acid binding
questions.explanation: Neuraminidase inhibitor mechanism: (1) NA function: Neuraminidase (NA) is a tetrameric glycoprotein enzyme (sialidase) on the influenza virion surface. It cleaves alpha-2,3 and alpha-2,6 sialic acid linkages. (2) NA roles in the viral life cycle: Virus release: NA cleaves sialic acid residues on the infected cell surface. Without this, newly budded virions remain attached to the cell via HA-sialic acid interactions (HA on the virion binds sialic acid on the cell). NA also removes sialic acid from viral glycoproteins (HA and NA themselves are glycosylated), preventing virion self-aggregation. Mucus penetration: NA cleaves sialic acid residues on mucins in the respiratory tract, allowing the virus to penetrate through the mucus layer to reach epithelial cells. (3) NA inhibitor design: Oseltamivir (Tamiflu, oral prodrug), zanamivir (Relenza, inhaled), peramivir (Rapivab, IV): These are transition-state analogs designed to mimic the oxocarbenium ion transition state of the NA-catalyzed sialic acid cleavage reaction. They bind with high affinity to the conserved catalytic site of NA, competitively inhibiting enzymatic activity. (4) Consequences of NA inhibition: Progeny virions bud normally from the infected cell but remain tethered to the cell surface via HA-sialic acid bonds. Virions aggregate into clumps (HA on one virion binds sialic acid on another). Viral spread from cell to cell and from the respiratory tract is blocked. However: initial infection of the cell is NOT prevented, intracellular viral replication proceeds normally, and the infected cell still produces virions. Therefore, NA inhibitors are most effective when given early (within 48 hours of symptom onset). (5) Resistance: The most common oseltamivir resistance mutation is H275Y (N2 numbering) or H274Y (N1 numbering) in NA, which reduces drug binding without eliminating enzymatic activity. Pre-2009 seasonal H1N1 had widespread H275Y resistance. Post-2009 pandemic H1N1 remains largely sensitive. Zanamivir resistance is rarer because zanamivir more closely resembles the natural substrate.

questions.question: Adenoviruses use a protein primer mechanism for DNA replication rather than an RNA primer. How does this work?
options: Adenovirus DNA replication uses a rolling circle mechanism like bacteriophage lambda
Adenovirus uses host primase to synthesize RNA primers like cellular DNA replication
Adenovirus DNA polymerase does not require any primer and initiates de novo

Adenovirus DNA replication uses a precursor terminal protein (pTP) covalently linked to a serine residue as a protein primer; the viral DNA polymerase forms a pTP-pol complex that binds the inverted terminal repeat (ITR) at the genome ends, the polymerase catalyzes the covalent attachment of the first nucleotide (dCMP) to pTP-Ser, and elongation proceeds by a strand displacement mechanism without the need for Okazaki fragments or a lagging strand
questions.explanation: Adenovirus protein-primed DNA replication: (1) Genome structure: Linear dsDNA genome (~36 kb) with inverted terminal repeats (ITRs, ~100-140 bp) at each end. Each 5' end is covalently linked to a terminal protein (TP, 55 kDa). (2) Initiation: The precursor terminal protein (pTP, 80 kDa) and the viral DNA polymerase (Ad pol) form a heterodimeric complex. This pTP-pol complex binds to the ITR at the genome end. Host nuclear factor I (NFI) and Oct-1 transcription factors enhance initiation by binding to sequences within the ITR adjacent to the origin. pTP provides a free hydroxyl group on Ser-580 (in human Ad5) as the primer terminus. Ad pol catalyzes the covalent addition of dCMP to pTP-Ser, forming a pTP-dCMP initiation complex. This occurs at position 4 of the ITR template (a GTA sequence). (3) Elongation: After addition of a few nucleotides (pTP-CAT), the complex jumps back to position 1-3 of the template (template slippage), aligning CAT with the conserved terminal GTA sequence. Elongation then proceeds continuously by strand displacement. The non-template strand is displaced as ssDNA. No lagging strand synthesis occurs — each strand is replicated independently. The displaced ssDNA is coated by viral DNA-binding protein (DBP), which also stimulates processivity. (4) Replication of the displaced strand: The displaced ssDNA can circularize through base-pairing of the ITR regions (forming a panhandle structure). The dsDNA ITR in the panhandle resembles a genome terminus and can serve as a new replication origin. A second pTP-pol complex initiates at this new origin, converting the panhandle to full-length dsDNA. (5) TP processing: After replication, pTP is cleaved to mature TP by the adenovirus-encoded protease (AVP) during virion maturation. TP remains covalently linked to the 5' ends of the genome in mature virions. (6) Advantages of protein priming: No need for Okazaki fragments, RNA primers, or a primase. No end-replication problem (because TP is always present at the 5' end). Efficient replication of linear genomes without telomerase. (7) Other viruses using protein primers: Phi29 bacteriophage (also protein-primed with strand displacement — the phi29 DNA polymerase is widely used in molecular biology for whole-genome amplification). Hepatitis B virus (pTP-like terminal protein primes minus-strand DNA synthesis).

questions.question: A researcher discovers a novel small RNA virus in insect cells. The purified virus particles contain an RNA genome but also a small amount of a protein that appears to be covalently attached to the 5' end of the RNA. How would they confirm this is a VPg (genome-linked protein) and determine its role?
options: Use mass spectrometry on intact virions without any RNA analysis

Treat purified viral RNA with proteinase K and compare migration on agarose gel electrophoresis with untreated RNA; if a VPg is present, proteinase K treatment will increase electrophoretic mobility because it removes the attached protein; additionally, demonstrate VPg function by showing that anti-VPg antibodies immunoprecipitate the genomic RNA, and that enzymatic removal of VPg abolishes in vitro translation if VPg substitutes for a cap, or prevents replication if VPg serves as a primer
Simply sequence the RNA to determine if a protein is attached
Perform Western blotting on purified RNA without any controls
questions.explanation: VPg characterization: (1) VPg (Virus Protein genome-linked) is a small protein (typically 2-4 kDa) covalently linked to the 5' end of the genomic RNA through a phosphodiester bond (typically VPg-Tyr-pUpU). Found in picornaviruses (3B/VPg), caliciviruses, potyviruses, and some other RNA virus families. (2) Confirming VPg presence: Proteinase K treatment: Degrade the protein component while preserving RNA. Proteinase K-treated RNA will migrate faster on agarose/polyacrylamide gels than untreated RNA because the attached protein retards electrophoretic mobility. The mobility shift should be ~2-4 kDa worth of mass. Immunoprecipitation: Raise antibodies against the candidate VPg protein. Anti-VPg antibodies should co-precipitate the viral RNA (pulldown assay). This confirms covalent linkage. Radiolabeling: Label RNA with 32P and proteins with 35S-Met. After gel electrophoresis, the VPg-RNA complex will show both labels at the same position. Proteinase K removes the 35S signal but not the 32P. (3) Determining VPg function: Cap substitute: Some VPgs serve as a 5' cap analog for translation initiation. Test by comparing in vitro translation of VPg-RNA vs. de-VPg-RNA (proteinase K treated). If VPg is required for translation, removing it will reduce or abolish translation. Calicivirus VPg directly recruits eIF4E for translation initiation. Replication primer: In picornaviruses, VPg-pUpU serves as the primer for RNA replication. The viral RdRp uridylylates VPg using a cis-acting RNA element (the cre element in poliovirus) as template. Test by: showing that anti-VPg antibodies inhibit in vitro replication, demonstrating uridylylation of purified VPg by the viral RdRp in vitro, and showing that mutations in the VPg tyrosine (Tyr-3 in poliovirus) abolish priming and are lethal. (4) Mass spectrometry: LC-MS/MS of protease-digested VPg-RNA junction peptide can identify the exact amino acid-nucleotide linkage and confirm the VPg identity.

questions.question: EBV (Epstein-Barr virus) uses distinct latency programs in different cell types and malignancies. What defines the different latency types, and how do they contribute to EBV-associated diseases?
options: All EBV-infected cells express all viral genes at all times
Latency types differ only in the copy number of viral episomes, not gene expression
EBV only has one latency program that is identical in all infected cells

EBV latency is classified by which viral genes are expressed: Latency III (all latent genes including EBNA1-6 and LMP1/2) drives immunoblastic proliferation in post-transplant lymphoma; Latency II (EBNA1, LMP1, LMP2A) is found in Hodgkin lymphoma and nasopharyngeal carcinoma; Latency I (EBNA1 only) maintains the viral episome in Burkitt lymphoma; Latency 0 (no viral proteins) represents the true quiescent state in resting memory B cells
questions.explanation: EBV latency programs: (1) EBV infects ~95% of the global adult population, establishing lifelong latency in memory B cells. Different latency programs represent a hierarchy of viral gene expression, each associated with different clinical outcomes. (2) Latency III (Growth program): All nine latent viral proteins expressed: EBNA1 (episome maintenance), EBNA2 (transcriptional activator, master regulator), EBNA3A/3B/3C (modulate host gene expression, interact with RBPJkappa), EBNA-LP (co-activator with EBNA2), LMP1 (constitutive CD40 mimic, activates NF-kappaB, mimics an activated TNF receptor), LMP2A (constitutive BCR mimic, provides survival signals). Drives B cell proliferation (immortalization). Found in: lymphoblastoid cell lines in vitro, post-transplant lymphoproliferative disease (PTLD) in immunosuppressed patients. Highly immunogenic — strongly targeted by CD8+ T cells in immunocompetent individuals. (3) Latency II (Default program): EBNA1, LMP1, LMP2A expressed. EBNA2 is silenced. Found in: Hodgkin lymphoma (Reed-Sternberg cells), nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC), gastric carcinoma, NK/T cell lymphoma. LMP1 provides constitutive NF-kappaB activation and anti-apoptotic signals. LMP2A mimics tonic BCR signaling (prevents apoptosis from lack of BCR signaling). (4) Latency I: Only EBNA1 expressed (plus non-coding RNAs: EBERs and miRNAs). EBNA1 maintains the episome by tethering it to host chromosomes during mitosis (it binds oriP on the viral episome and host chromosomal attachment sites). Found in: Burkitt lymphoma (endemic form). The c-myc translocation (t(8;14), t(2;8), or t(8;22)) provides the proliferative drive; EBNA1 just maintains the episome. Minimally immunogenic because EBNA1 contains a Gly-Ala repeat that inhibits proteasomal processing, reducing MHC-I presentation. (5) Latency 0: No viral protein expression. Only EBERs (small non-coding RNAs, ~10^7 copies per cell) and BamHI-A rightward transcripts (BARTs including miRNAs). Represents the true quiescent state in circulating memory B cells. The virus maintains its episome through host cell division (EBNA1 is transiently expressed during S phase for episome replication, then silenced). (6) Transition model: Initial B cell infection → Latency III (proliferation, germinal center colonization) → Latency II (germinal center transit) → Latency I or 0 (memory B cell reservoir). Periodic lytic reactivation from memory B cells produces infectious virus for transmission.
questions.topic: EBV latency programs and associated malignancies

questions.question: Segmented genome viruses like influenza must coordinate the packaging of exactly one copy of each segment. How does influenza ensure accurate segment assortment?
options: A viral protein counts the number of segments and only allows budding when all eight are present
Each segment is randomly packaged and virions with incorrect complements are simply non-functional
All eight segments are physically linked end-to-end as a single RNA molecule

Influenza uses selective packaging through cis-acting packaging signals located in the 5' and 3' UTRs and adjacent coding regions of each vRNA segment; these signals form segment-specific RNA-RNA interactions (a supramolecular complex) that ensure one copy of each of the eight segments is incorporated into budding virions through a hierarchical assembly mechanism, though occasional errors produce virions missing segments
questions.explanation: Influenza segment packaging: (1) Challenge: Influenza A has 8 distinct vRNA segments (PB2, PB1, PA, HA, NP, NA, M, NS). Each must be present for the virion to be infectious. If packaging were random, the probability of getting all 8 by chance = (1/8)^7 = 1/2,097,152 — far too low for viable infection. (2) Selective packaging: cis-acting packaging signals are located at the 3' and 5' termini of each vRNA segment, extending into the adjacent coding regions (typically 20-120 nt of coding sequence at each end). These signals are segment-specific — swapping them between segments redirects packaging. (3) RNA-RNA interactions: In vitro studies show that the 8 vRNA segments form specific inter-segment RNA-RNA base-pairing interactions. These form a supramolecular complex in which each segment contacts at least one other segment. Mutations disrupting these interactions reduce packaging efficiency. Electron tomography of budding virions reveals the 8 RNP segments arranged in a '7+1' configuration (7 segments surrounding 1 central segment). (4) Sequential/hierarchical assembly: Evidence suggests segments are incorporated in a specific order. Some segments (e.g., NA, NS) are more frequently lost than others, suggesting they are added later in the assembly process. The packaging signals and inter-segment interactions create a cooperative network — loss of one segment reduces the packaging of others. (5) Packaging errors: Despite selective packaging, errors occur at ~1-10% frequency. Virions missing one or more segments can still infect if complemented by co-infection with a second virion carrying the missing segment(s). Semi-infectious particles (SIPs) may contribute to multiplicity reactivation. (6) Implication for reassortment: Selective packaging constrains reassortment — not all segment combinations are equally viable. Incompatible packaging signals between distantly related influenza viruses may limit the range of reassortant viruses that can form.

questions.question: Tetherin (BST-2/CD317) is an interferon-stimulated gene product that restricts enveloped virus release. How does tetherin function mechanistically, and how do different viruses counteract it?
options: Tetherin functions as a receptor that sequesters viruses inside endosomes
Tetherin only restricts non-enveloped viruses by crosslinking their capsids
Tetherin is a nuclease that degrades viral genomes at the cell surface

Tetherin is a dimeric type II transmembrane protein with an unusual dual-anchor topology (N-terminal transmembrane domain and C-terminal GPI anchor); it physically tethers budding virions to the cell surface by inserting one anchor into the cell membrane and the other into the virion envelope, preventing viral spread; HIV-1 Vpu counteracts tetherin by targeting it for ubiquitin-dependent degradation, while Ebola VP40 and KSHV K5 use different mechanisms to antagonize tetherin
questions.explanation: Tetherin antiviral mechanism: (1) Tetherin structure: Type II transmembrane protein with a unique topology. From N-terminus: short cytoplasmic tail, single transmembrane domain, coiled-coil ectodomain, GPI (glycosylphosphatidylinositol) anchor at C-terminus. Forms parallel homodimers via ectodomain disulfide bonds. (2) Mechanism of action: One membrane anchor (either TM or GPI) is in the host cell plasma membrane. The other anchor becomes embedded in the virion membrane during budding. The coiled-coil ectodomain spans between them. This creates a physical bridge (tether) that prevents the virion from detaching from the cell surface. Tethered virions are then internalized by endocytosis and degraded in lysosomes. Tetherin is an ISG — its expression is strongly induced by type I interferons. It restricts all enveloped viruses tested (it is broad-spectrum because it acts on the membrane, not on any specific viral protein). (3) HIV-1 Vpu counteraction: Vpu is a small transmembrane protein encoded by HIV-1 (not HIV-2 or most SIVs). Vpu binds tetherin's transmembrane domain via its own transmembrane domain. Vpu recruits the SCF-beta-TrCP E3 ubiquitin ligase to tetherin's cytoplasmic tail. Tetherin is ubiquitinated and targeted for proteasomal and lysosomal degradation. Additionally, Vpu sequesters newly synthesized tetherin in the trans-Golgi network, preventing its transport to the plasma membrane. (4) Other viral antagonists: HIV-2 and most SIVs: Envelope protein (gp41) and/or Nef antagonize tetherin (lineage-specific adaptations). Ebola VP40: Counteracts tetherin by an incompletely understood mechanism. KSHV K5 (MIR2): A viral E3 ubiquitin ligase that ubiquitinates tetherin, directing it to lysosomes. Sendai virus and other paramyxoviruses: May use matrix or fusion proteins. (5) Evolutionary significance: Tetherin is under strong positive selection across primate lineages, particularly in the transmembrane domain that interacts with Vpu — evidence of a host-pathogen arms race. The species-specificity of tetherin-Vpu interaction constrains cross-species transmission of lentiviruses.
questions.topic: Tetherin antiviral restriction and viral countermeasures

questions.question: Viral recombination in retroviruses occurs at a high rate during reverse transcription. What structural feature of the retroviral virion enables this, and what is the mechanism?
options: Retroviruses package two copies of their genomic RNA as a non-covalently linked dimer; during reverse transcription, RT can switch from one RNA template to the other (forced copy-choice) at sites of template damage, secondary structure, or sequence homology, generating recombinant proviral DNA at a rate of 2-3 crossovers per genome per replication cycle in HIV-1
Retroviral recombination only occurs between distantly related viruses
Retroviral recombination requires host recombinases like RecA
Retroviruses package only one RNA copy and recombination occurs by breakage and reunion of proviral DNA
questions.explanation: Retroviral recombination mechanism: (1) Diploid genome: Retroviruses are the only viruses that package two complete copies of their RNA genome per virion. The two (+) ssRNA molecules are non-covalently linked near their 5' ends through a dimer linkage structure (DLS) — a kissing-loop interaction where palindromic sequences in each RNA base-pair with each other. (2) Heterozygous virions: If a cell is co-infected by two different retroviruses of the same species, random co-packaging can produce heterozygous virions containing one RNA from each parent. Recombination only occurs if the virion is heterozygous. (3) Copy-choice mechanism during reverse transcription: During minus-strand DNA synthesis, RT encounters template breaks, secondary structures, or pauses. RT (with the nascent DNA still attached) dissociates from one RNA template and transfers to the co-packaged RNA at the same or nearby position. Synthesis continues on the new template. This is facilitated by the proximity of the two RNAs within the nucleocapsid and by NC protein chaperone activity. (4) Obligatory template switches: Two template switches are already built into normal reverse transcription (first and second strand transfers). Additional 'internal' template switches generate recombinants. (5) Recombination rate in HIV-1: ~2-3 crossovers per genome per replication cycle. Over ~10^10 replication cycles per day, this generates enormous recombinant diversity. 15-20% of globally circulating HIV-1 strains are circulating recombinant forms (CRFs). CRF02_AG is the most prevalent recombinant globally. (6) Biological significance: Recombination combines beneficial mutations from different viral genomes. It can bring together drug resistance mutations from different parents. It accelerates adaptation to new environments. It can repair damaged genomes. It increases the effective population size for evolutionary purposes. (7) The diploid genome as an evolutionary advantage: Diploidy provides recombination, template damage repair, and genetic buffering — advantages shared with sexual reproduction in eukaryotes.
questions.topic: Retroviral diploid genome and copy-choice recombination

questions.question: Bacteriophage phi29 uses a unique packaging motor that can be studied in single-molecule experiments. What makes the phi29 system particularly valuable for biophysics research?
options: Phi29 uses a completely different packaging mechanism from other phages with no shared components
Phi29 does not require ATP for DNA packaging

Phi29 has a small genome (~19 kb) packaged by a well-characterized molecular motor consisting of a dodecameric portal (gp10), a pentameric ATPase ring (gp16), and a unique hexameric pRNA (packaging RNA) ring that is essential for motor function; its manageable size allows real-time single-molecule measurements using optical tweezers, revealing packaging velocity, force generation (~57 pN stall force), and step size (~2.5 bp per ATPase event) with unprecedented resolution
Phi29 packaging can only be studied by bulk biochemical assays
questions.explanation: Phi29 as a model packaging motor: (1) Phi29 overview: A Bacillus subtilis phage with a small genome (~19.3 kb linear dsDNA with terminal protein gp3 covalently attached to each 5' end). Its small size and well-characterized components make it the premier model for studying viral DNA packaging motors. (2) Motor components: Portal (gp10): A dodecameric (12-subunit) ring that forms a channel at a unique vertex of the prolate icosahedral capsid. The DNA passes through the central channel (~3.6 nm diameter). Connector between the prohead and the packaging machinery. ATPase (gp16): A pentameric ring that sits at the distal end of the portal. ASCE (Additional Strand Conserved E) superfamily ATPase. Each subunit hydrolyzes ATP and translocates DNA. pRNA: A unique feature of phi29 — a pentameric ring of small RNA molecules (~120 nt each) that bridges the portal and the ATPase. pRNA is essential for packaging; its removal abolishes motor function. The pRNA intermolecular interactions (hand-in-glove or interlocking loop) form the pentameric ring. (3) Single-molecule optical tweezers experiments: A single prohead is attached to one bead, and the end of the DNA is attached to another bead. Optical traps hold the beads with known force. As the motor packages DNA, the beads move together. Measurements reveal: Packaging velocity: ~100-200 bp/sec (one of the fastest known molecular motors). Stall force: ~57 pN (the force at which the motor stops — this is the maximum force the motor can generate against internal capsid pressure). Step size: ~2.5 bp per ATPase event (10 bp per power stroke cycle for the 4 active subunits in the pentamer). The motor pauses and slips as the capsid fills, reflecting the increasing internal pressure. (4) Mechanochemical cycle: ATP binding and hydrolysis are sequential around the pentameric ring. Current models suggest a 'push-roll' or 'inchworm' mechanism. The motor alternates between a DNA-gripping phase (ATP-bound) and a translocation phase (ADP+Pi release). (5) Applications: Understanding phi29 packaging has inspired nanobiotechnology applications — the phi29 motor has been re-engineered as a nanodevice for DNA sequencing, drug delivery, and molecular sensing. The pRNA component has been developed as a platform for RNA nanotechnology.

questions.question: A neutralization assay shows that antibodies raised against the SARS-CoV-2 Wuhan-Hu-1 spike protein have a 50% inhibitory concentration (IC50) of 0.05 ug/mL against the original strain, 0.15 ug/mL against the Delta variant, and 2.5 ug/mL against the Omicron BA.1 variant. How should these results be interpreted?
options: The differences are within normal experimental error and are not significant
IC50 values cannot be compared between different viral variants

The increasing IC50 values indicate progressive immune evasion: a higher antibody concentration is needed to neutralize the variant, reflecting reduced antibody-spike affinity due to mutations in the receptor binding domain and N-terminal domain antigenic sites; the ~50-fold reduction for Omicron BA.1 (2.5/0.05 = 50) indicates substantial but not complete immune escape, explaining breakthrough infections in vaccinated individuals while severe disease is still prevented by residual neutralization and T cell immunity
Lower IC50 always indicates weaker neutralization, so the original strain is the most resistant
questions.explanation: Interpreting neutralization assay IC50 values: (1) IC50 definition: The concentration of antibody (or serum dilution) required to reduce viral infection by 50% in a standardized assay (typically plaque reduction, microneutralization, or pseudovirus assay). Lower IC50 = more potent neutralization (less antibody needed). Higher IC50 = weaker neutralization (more antibody needed). (2) Fold-change analysis: Delta vs Wuhan: 0.15/0.05 = 3-fold reduction. This modest reduction explains why vaccines remained highly effective against Delta for preventing severe disease. Omicron BA.1 vs Wuhan: 2.5/0.05 = 50-fold reduction. This substantial reduction explains widespread breakthrough infections in vaccinated individuals. (3) Molecular basis of immune evasion: Omicron BA.1 has ~30 mutations in the spike protein, including 15 in the RBD. Key escape mutations: K417N, N440K, G446S, S477N, T478K, E484A, Q493R, G496S, Q498R, N501Y, Y505H. These mutations alter the epitopes recognized by most RBD-directed neutralizing antibodies (Class 1-4 antibodies). N-terminal domain (NTD) mutations and deletions also eliminate NTD-directed antibody binding. (4) Clinical implications: Despite 50-fold reduced neutralization, Omicron BA.1 did not cause proportionally more severe disease because: Residual neutralizing activity still provides some protection. Memory B cells can rapidly produce cross-reactive antibodies. T cell responses (CD4+ and CD8+) target conserved epitopes throughout the spike protein (and other viral proteins) that are less affected by mutations. T cell epitope conservation between Wuhan and Omicron is ~80-90%. (5) Vaccine update rationale: When neutralization drops >10-fold, vaccine updates are considered. Bivalent and updated monovalent boosters were developed targeting variant spikes. (6) Assay considerations: Pseudovirus assays (using VSV or lentiviral backbones bearing SARS-CoV-2 spike) correlate well with live virus assays but may slightly overestimate or underestimate neutralization depending on the system.

questions.question: Arboviruses (arthropod-borne viruses) must replicate in both vertebrate and invertebrate hosts. What evolutionary constraint does this dual-host lifestyle impose?
options: Arboviruses evolve faster than single-host viruses because they experience more diverse selection pressures

Arboviruses must maintain fitness in both mammalian cells (37 degrees C, interferon-based immunity) and arthropod cells (25-28 degrees C, RNAi-based immunity), which constrains their evolution because mutations beneficial in one host may be deleterious in the other; this evolutionary trade-off results in lower evolutionary rates compared to single-host RNA viruses, as the virus occupies a fitness compromise between two very different selective environments
Arboviruses only replicate in the arthropod and use the vertebrate host passively for transmission
The dual-host requirement has no effect on arbovirus evolution because RNA polymerase fidelity is the only factor
questions.explanation: Arbovirus evolutionary constraints: (1) Dual-host biology: Arboviruses (dengue, Zika, chikungunya, West Nile, yellow fever, etc.) must complete their life cycle in both: Vertebrate host: Replication at 37 degrees C (mammals) or 38-42 degrees C (birds). Immune evasion of innate (interferon, ISGs) and adaptive (antibodies, T cells) immune responses. High viremia required for mosquito acquisition. Arthropod vector: Replication at ambient temperature (25-28 degrees C). Immune evasion of RNAi-based and Toll/Imd pathway-based innate immunity. Persistent non-pathogenic infection of salivary glands for transmission. (2) Evolutionary constraint — fitness trade-offs: Mutations that increase fitness in vertebrate cells may decrease fitness in arthropod cells, and vice versa. Example: Codon usage differs between mammalian and insect cells (different tRNA abundances). Optimal codon usage for one host is suboptimal for the other. Temperature-sensitive mutations: A mutation that improves protein folding at 37 degrees C may destabilize it at 28 degrees C. Interferon antagonism proteins may be unnecessary or even costly in arthropod cells. (3) Evidence for purifying selection: Arboviruses show lower dN/dS ratios (~0.05-0.1) compared to single-host RNA viruses. Their evolutionary rate is 10-100 fold lower than single-host viruses like HIV or influenza. Serial passage in a single host (vertebrate OR arthropod cells only) leads to rapid adaptation to that host but decreased fitness in the alternate host. (4) Experimental evidence: Classic alternate-passage experiments: Passaging an arbovirus alternately between mammalian and mosquito cells maintains broad host range. Passaging only in mammalian cells → gains fitness in mammalian cells, loses fitness in mosquito cells. Passaging only in mosquito cells → gains fitness in mosquito cells, loses fitness in mammalian cells. This demonstrates the host-alternation constraint directly. (5) Implications: The dual-host constraint explains why arboviruses are genetically relatively stable compared to human-only respiratory viruses. It also constrains vaccine development — live attenuated arbovirus vaccines must remain attenuated in BOTH human and mosquito hosts to prevent reversion and onward transmission.

questions.question: The concept of the RNA World hypothesis proposes that RNA preceded DNA and proteins as the primary genetic and catalytic molecule. What evidence from modern viruses supports this hypothesis?
options: Modern viruses provide no evidence relevant to the RNA World hypothesis

Several viral features support the RNA World: ribozymes in hepatitis delta virus and viroids demonstrate catalytic RNA without proteins; RNA replication by RdRps shows RNA can direct its own replication; the diversity of RNA virus replication strategies across Baltimore classes suggests RNA genomes preceded DNA genomes; and retroelements (using RNA-to-DNA conversion) represent a plausible transition mechanism from RNA to DNA genomes
All viruses have DNA genomes, contradicting the RNA World
RNA viruses evolved from DNA viruses, not the other way around
questions.explanation: Viral evidence for the RNA World: (1) Catalytic RNA (ribozymes) in viruses: Hepatitis delta virus (HDV): Uses a self-cleaving ribozyme for processing its circular RNA genome during rolling circle replication. The HDV ribozyme catalyzes a site-specific transesterification reaction without any protein. Viroids (PSTVd family): Use hammerhead ribozymes for self-cleavage of rolling circle replication intermediates. These are among the simplest known ribozymes, demonstrating that very small RNA structures can have catalytic activity. Group I and Group II self-splicing introns found in some phages (T4 Group I introns). (2) RNA as genetic material: The vast diversity of RNA viruses (Baltimore Classes III, IV, V, VI) demonstrates that RNA is a perfectly functional genetic material. RNA genomes can encode all the information needed for viral replication, assembly, and host manipulation. RNA viruses represent the majority of known virus species. (3) RNA-dependent RNA replication: RdRps (found in all RNA viruses except retroviruses) copy RNA from an RNA template — demonstrating that RNA replication without DNA is biochemically feasible. This is the type of replication that would have been required in an RNA World. Modern RdRps are protein enzymes, but they show that the chemical process of RNA-templated RNA synthesis is viable. (4) Retroelements as transitional relics: Retroviruses (Class VI) and pararetroviruses (Class VII, like HBV) use reverse transcriptase to convert RNA to DNA. This RNA→DNA conversion is precisely the type of transition that would have been needed to move from an RNA World to a DNA World. RT is found throughout cellular genomes (retroelements, telomerase reverse transcriptase), suggesting this activity predates the divergence of cellular life. (5) Viroid arguments: Viroids (small circular RNAs, no protein coat, replicated entirely by host enzymes) may represent relics of the RNA World — molecular fossils of pre-cellular self-replicating RNA elements. Their small size (~250-400 nt), compact structure, ribozyme activity, and absence of protein-coding capacity resemble what primitive RNA replicators might have looked like. (6) Caveats: Viruses are obligate parasites of cells, so they cannot be direct relics of the RNA World. However, the mechanisms they use (RNA catalysis, RNA replication, reverse transcription) provide proof-of-concept that these processes are biochemically possible.
questions.topic: Viral evidence for the RNA World hypothesis

questions.question: Viral metagenomics has revolutionized virus discovery. How does shotgun metagenomics detect novel viruses compared to traditional cell culture-based approaches?
options: Metagenomics can only detect DNA viruses, not RNA viruses

Shotgun metagenomics extracts total nucleic acids from environmental or clinical samples, randomly fragments them, sequences all fragments using next-generation sequencing, and uses bioinformatics (assembly and comparison to known viral databases) to identify viral sequences; this culture-independent approach has revealed enormous previously unknown viral diversity including thousands of novel virus species from oceans, soils, and the human virome that cannot be grown in standard cell cultures
Traditional cell culture remains the only reliable method for discovering new viruses
Metagenomics requires growing viruses in cell culture before sequencing
questions.explanation: Viral metagenomics: (1) Traditional virus discovery limitations: Requires cell culture — many viruses cannot grow in standard laboratory cell lines (no permissive cell line, fastidious growth requirements). Only detects viruses that cause visible cytopathic effect (CPE). Biased toward viruses of medical/agricultural importance. (2) Shotgun metagenomics workflow: Sample collection (water, soil, blood, feces, respiratory secretions, tissues). Nucleic acid extraction (DNA and/or RNA; for RNA viruses, reverse transcription to cDNA). Optional: Enrichment by filtration (remove bacteria/cells, concentrate virus-sized particles), nuclease treatment (remove free nucleic acids, protect encapsidated genomes). Random fragmentation and library preparation. Next-generation sequencing (Illumina, Oxford Nanopore, PacBio). Bioinformatics: quality filtering, assembly (de novo or reference-based), taxonomic classification (comparison to databases like NCBI RefSeq, UniProt), phylogenetic analysis. Novel viruses: sequences with no close matches to known viruses (often identified by conserved RdRp, capsid protein, or polymerase motifs). (3) Discoveries enabled by metagenomics: Ocean virome: The Global Ocean Virome study identified ~200,000 viral populations, vastly expanding the known diversity of marine bacteriophages. Human virome: The human gut contains ~10^9 virus-like particles per gram of feces, mostly bacteriophages. CrAssphage (cross-Assembly phage): the most abundant virus in the human gut, discovered entirely through metagenomics in 2014 — never cultured until 2018. Giant viruses: Klosneuvirus, Tupanvirus, and other giant virus lineages discovered from metagenomic data. Invertebrate and environmental viromes: RNA virus diversity is orders of magnitude greater than previously known. The 2016 study by Shi et al. in Nature doubled the number of known RNA virus families using invertebrate metagenomics. (4) Limitations: Cannot determine if a viral sequence is from an infectious virus (may be endogenous, defective, or degraded). Assembly errors can create chimeric sequences. Quantification is relative, not absolute (without spike-in controls). Database-dependent — truly novel viruses with no homology to known sequences may be missed. Cannot determine host range without additional experiments (culturing, in situ hybridization). (5) Impact: Metagenomics has shifted virology from a culture-based science to a sequence-based science. It enables pandemic preparedness by surveilling animal reservoirs for pre-emergent viruses.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about antiviral drug mechanisms:

S1: Nucleoside analog inhibitors like acyclovir require phosphorylation by a viral kinase (HSV thymidine kinase) for activation, providing selectivity for virus-infected cells.

S2: HIV protease inhibitors block the cleavage of Gag and Gag-Pol polyproteins, resulting in production of immature, non-infectious virions.

S3: Interferon-alpha treatment directly kills virus-infected cells through the induction of apoptosis, with no effect on uninfected neighboring cells.

S4: Entry inhibitors like maraviroc bind the viral receptor (CD4) to prevent HIV attachment to target cells.
options: T, T, F, F
T, T, T, F
T, F, F, F
T, T, F, T
questions.explanation: Analyzing antiviral drug mechanism statements: S1 TRUE: Acyclovir (acycloguanosine) is a guanosine analog that requires three phosphorylation steps for activation. The first (rate-limiting) phosphorylation is performed by HSV or VZV thymidine kinase (TK), which has broader substrate specificity than cellular TK. Subsequent phosphorylations are by cellular kinases. Acyclovir triphosphate is incorporated by viral DNA polymerase (which has higher affinity for it than cellular polymerase) and causes chain termination (lacking 3'-OH). This double selectivity (viral TK activation + viral polymerase incorporation) minimizes toxicity to uninfected cells. Resistance arises through TK mutations (most common) or DNA polymerase mutations. S2 TRUE: HIV protease inhibitors (ritonavir, darunavir, atazanavir) bind the active site of HIV aspartyl protease, preventing cleavage of Gag and Gag-Pol polyproteins. Without proteolytic processing, the MA-CA-NC-p6 polyprotein remains uncleaved. Virions bud but contain unprocessed polyproteins, resulting in immature, non-infectious particles with aberrant morphology (lack the mature conical core). This is why protease inhibitors are potent components of combination therapy. S3 FALSE: Interferon-alpha does not directly kill infected cells through apoptosis (although some ISGs can promote apoptosis). IFN-alpha primarily induces an antiviral state in BOTH infected and uninfected neighboring cells by: activating JAK-STAT signaling → ISG induction → PKR (translational shutoff), OAS/RNase L (RNA degradation), MxA (viral assembly block), IFITM (entry block). IFN-alpha acts on uninfected cells too (paracrine signaling), pre-arming them against infection. Some ISGs do promote apoptosis (TRAIL, Fas), but this is not the primary mechanism and IFN-alpha certainly affects uninfected cells. S4 FALSE: Maraviroc does NOT bind CD4. Maraviroc is a CCR5 antagonist — it binds the CCR5 coreceptor (a human chemokine receptor) and induces a conformational change that prevents HIV gp120 from binding CCR5. It only blocks R5-tropic HIV (not X4-tropic). It is the entry inhibitor (CCR5 antagonist), not a receptor blocker. The other HIV entry inhibitor, enfuvirtide (T-20), is a peptide that mimics the HR2 region of gp41, blocking the six-helix bundle formation needed for membrane fusion.

questions.question: Lysogeny-lysis decision in phage lambda is a paradigmatic example of a genetic switch. Beyond the CI-Cro bistable switch, what environmental factors influence whether lambda enters lysogeny or the lytic cycle upon initial infection?
options: The host cell always determines the outcome regardless of the phage genotype

The lysogeny-lysis decision is influenced by multiplicity of infection (MOI) and host nutritional status: at high MOI, the CII protein accumulates to higher levels (because more phage genomes produce more CII), activating the pI and pRE promoters to express CI repressor and Int, favoring lysogeny; the host protease FtsH (HflB) degrades CII, and its activity is modulated by bacterial growth conditions — starving bacteria have reduced FtsH activity, favoring CII accumulation and lysogeny
Only the temperature of the growth medium determines lysis vs lysogeny
The decision is entirely random with no environmental influence
questions.explanation: Lambda lysogeny-lysis decision: (1) The CII protein as the decision maker: CII is a transcriptional activator produced from the early pR transcript. CII activates three promoters: pRE (promoter for repressor establishment) → CI repressor expression. pI (promoter for integrase) → Int protein for prophage integration. pAQ (antisense promoter) → antisense RNA that inhibits Q antitermination factor expression. High CII → CI + Int → lysogeny. Low CII → no CI, Q activates late genes → lytic cycle. (2) CII stability and FtsH protease: CII is inherently unstable (half-life ~2 min) because it is a target for the host protease FtsH (HflB, an AAA+ protease in the inner membrane). The phage CIII protein acts as an anti-protease — CIII inhibits FtsH, protecting CII from degradation. The balance between CII synthesis, CIII protection, and FtsH degradation determines CII levels. (3) MOI effect: At high MOI (multiple phages infecting one cell): More phage genomes produce more CII and CIII proteins. CII accumulates faster than FtsH can degrade it. High CII → CI activation → lysogeny. At low MOI (one phage per cell): Limited CII production. FtsH degrades CII before it reaches threshold. Low CII → lytic development. (4) Host nutritional status: In nutrient-rich conditions: Cells grow rapidly, FtsH is highly active. CII is rapidly degraded → favors lytic cycle. The phage can exploit the abundant resources for rapid replication. In nutrient-poor conditions (starvation): Reduced growth rate, reduced FtsH activity. CII is more stable → favors lysogeny. Lysogeny is advantageous because the phage genome is maintained as the host enters a dormant state — the phage 'waits' for better conditions. (5) Additional factors: cAMP-CRP levels (catabolite repression indicator) influence the decision through effects on host gene expression. DNA damage response (RecA activation) directly affects the CI switch after initial establishment (prophage induction, as discussed in the CI repressor question).
